theorem_statement:
\label{iden-2} Let $n$ be a positive integer and let $A$ be a set of positive integers. We have
(a)  \[ \sum_{k=1}^{n}N^p_A(k)\left(q_A^e(n-k)-q_A^o(n-k)\right)=\tau_A(n), \]
(b)  \[ \sum_{k=1}^nN^q_A(k)\left(p_A^e(n-k)-p_A^o(n-k)\right)=\tau_A^s(n). \]
generated_proof:
### Proof Sketch
- Start from the generating functions in Theorem 1: for N_A^p, multiply its generating function by ∏_{a∈A}(1−x^a); for N_A^q, multiply its generating function by ∏_{a∈A}(1+x^a)^{-1}.
- Observe the classical parity-generating identities:
  - ∏_{a∈A}(1−x^a) = ∑_{n≥0} (q_A^e(n)−q_A^o(n)) x^n.
  - ∏_{a∈A}(1+x^a)^{-1} = ∑_{n≥0} (p_A^e(n)−p_A^o(n)) x^n.
- Also note the divisor-sum expansions:
  - ∑_{b∈A} x^b/(1−x^b) = ∑_{n≥1} τ_A(n) x^n.
  - ∑_{b∈A} x^b/(1+x^b) = ∑_{n≥1} τ_A^s(n) x^n.
- After the multiplications, the left-hand sides become Cauchy products whose coefficients are precisely the convolutions in the theorem; the right-hand sides become the τ-series. Coefficient extraction yields the desired identities.

### Proof
We work throughout with formal power series in x.

Step 1: Parity generating functions.
- For distinct partitions with parts in A, the bivariate generating function with z marking the number of parts is ∏_{a∈A}(1+z x^a). Setting z=−1 gives
  ∏_{a∈A}(1−x^a) = ∑_{n

sections.title: Generating Functions for $N_A^p(n)$ and $N_A^q(n)$, and Six ways to Convolution and Recurrence Identities
Asymptotic Estimate of $N_A^p(n)$ when $A$ is a Finite Set
